content:
- 5 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
However, the immediate orientation of the actual work carried out at the Centres 'is of a taxonomic rather than of an epidemiological character. It would therefore be more accurate to say that the Centres' immediate purposes are (a) taxonomic while one of their ultimate purposes, indirectly achieved by merely concentrating on (a), is to contribute towards the basic information necessary for full development of (b) epidemiological studies.
A closer analysis of the Centres' taxonomic and nomenclatural interests and responsibilities is necessary, and is as follows. It involves a consideration of the rôle played by the International Association of Microbiological Societies in this general field of work.
In the biological sciences the establishment of taxonomic and nomenclatural systems is a fundamental necessity. The mere establishment of such a system is, however, an academic and sterile achievement unless it is followed by the next logical step, on the more practical plane, of providing the means by which workers, far and wide, are able to identify, within that system, the natural elements and components (in this case enteric bacterial species, types and sub-types) for which the system has been created. The first of these requirements, namely, the establishment and elaboration of taxonomic and nomenclatural systems for the enteric (as well as for other) micro-organisms is a cern JAM 3.0 mit Tud
concern of the IAMS, which it achieves through its International Committee and Judicial Commission on Bacteriological Nomenclature, the International Committee relying for guidance in the field of enteric bacteriology on its Enterobacteriaceae Subcommittee. And it is the International Centres, under WHO aegis, which provide the logical practical extension of this initial basic requirement, namely, exploitation of the taxonomic and nomenclatural systems established by the IAMS, by making available the working materials for, and facilitating everywhere the identification of, enteric bacteria within those systems.
ANALYSIS OF THE BASIC FUNCTIONS OF THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRES, AND THEIR FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS
(b) TO THE NATIONAL CENTRES
In order to achieve its purpose of facilitating, throughout the world, the identification of the enteric groups with which they are concerned, the International Centres cannot, of course, work in isolation, but are axiomatically dependent on contacts with other laboratories throughout the world. These are the National Salmonella Centres
國史饭 Academia Historica

However, the immediate orientation of the actual work carried out at the Centres 'is of a taxonomic rather than of an epidemiological character. concern of the IAMS, which it achieves through its International Committee and Judicial Commission on Bacteriological Nomenclature, the International Committee relying for guidance in the field of enteric bacteriology on its Enterobacteriaceae Subcommittee.
